_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The four kinds of oxen [an4.108:5.6]: One hostile to its own herd, not others
One hostile to other herds, not its own
One hostile to both its own herd and others
One hostile to neither its own herd nor others
The four people similar to oxen found in: One hostile to their own herd, not others
One hostile to other herds, not their own
One hostile to both their own herd and others
One hostile to neither their own herd nor others
How a person is hostile to their own her: A person intimidates their own followers, not the followers of others
How a person is hostile to other herds,: A person intimidates the followers of others, not their own
How a person is hostile to both their ow: A person intimidates their own followers and the followers of others
How a person is hostile to neither their: A person doesnâ€™t intimidate their own followers or the followers of others
